bestBHT.bht: The people waited until the Sabbath hours were over to bring their sick to Jesus for a cure. It was deemed unlawful to do so during that time. Jesus showed the people how superstitious it was to strain the Sabbath rest. As the Sabbath ended at sunset, people were now free to bring the sick and possessed to Jesus. They did so in crowds, with Jesus laying His hands on each one as they moved in a grateful procession.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: From Luke 13:14 we see how unlawful they would have deemed it to bring their sick to Jesus for a cure during the sabbath hours.
Our Lord afterwards took repeated occasion to teach the people by example, even at the risk of His own life, how superstitious a straining of the sabbath rest this was.
They waited, therefore, till these [sabbath hours] were over, and then brought them in crowds.
Marvin Vincent: At even, when the sun did set
Philip Schaff: The Sabbath had ended, and they felt at liberty to bring the sick and possessed.
Them that were possessed with demons, or, more literally, 'those demonized, under the power of evil spirits.'
The two afflicted classes are distinguished.
Archibald T. Robertson: The sabbath ended at sunset and so the people were now at liberty to bring their sick to Jesus.
The news about the casting out of the demon and the healing of Peter's mother-in-law had spread all over Capernaum.
They brought them in a steady stream... Jesus laid his hand on every one of them as they passed by in grateful procession.
John Gill: At which time the Jews' sabbath was ended; for this was a sabbath day... the sabbath was over."
They brought unto him all that were diseased; with any sort of disease whatever, even all that were in their city.
The Persic version renders it 'epileptics', such as were troubled with the falling sickness, as many of those were, whose bodies the devils possessed.
John Wesley: When the sun was set — And, consequently, the Sabbath was ended, which they reckoned from sunset to sunset.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Mark 1:32, it is noted how the people waited until the Sabbath hours were over to bring their sick to Jesus for a cure, as it would have been deemed unlawful to do so during that time. Jesus, in His example, demonstrated how superstitious it was to strain the Sabbath rest. As the Sabbath ended at sunset, people were now free to bring the sick and possessed to Jesus. They did so in crowds, with Jesus laying His hands on each one as they passed by in a grateful procession.

The people in this passage waited until the Sabbath hours were over to bring their sick to Jesus for a cure. It was deemed unlawful to do so during that time. Jesus, in His example, demonstrated how superstitious it was to strain the Sabbath rest. As the Sabbath ended at sunset, people were now free to bring the sick and possessed to Jesus. They did so in crowds, with Jesus laying His hands on each one as they passed by in a grateful procession.

The people waited until the Sabbath hours were over to bring their sick to Jesus for a cure. It was deemed unlawful to do so during that time. Jesus showed the people how superstitious it was to strain the Sabbath rest. As the Sabbath ended at sunset, people were now free to bring the sick and possessed to Jesus. They did so in crowds, with Jesus laying His hands on each one as they moved in a grateful procession.

After the Sabbath hours were over, people flocked to Jesus with their sick and possessed. It had been deemed unlawful to seek healing on the Sabbath, but Jesus taught by example, risking His own life to show the superstitious nature of this belief. The news of His previous miracles had spread, and the people brought their loved ones to Jesus for healing. They formed a grateful procession, and Jesus laid His hands on each one as they passed by. The Sabbath had ended at sunset, and now the people were at liberty to seek Jesus' healing touch for their ailments.

After the Sabbath hours were over, people waited to bring their sick and possessed to Jesus, as it was forbidden to seek healing on the Sabbath. Jesus risked His life to teach by example, showing the superstitious nature of this belief. Word spread about His previous miracles, and the community of Capernaum gathered in a grateful procession, bringing their loved ones to Jesus for healing. At sunset, the Sabbath ended, allowing the people the freedom to seek Jesus' healing touch.
